• Overview
  • Importance
  • Cardiac Cycle & Blood Composition
  • Disorders
  • Sources

Cardiac Cycle: The cardiac cycle consists of several stages:

  • Atrial Contraction: The atria contract, pushing blood into the ventricles.

  • Ventricular Contraction: The ventricles contract, pumping blood out of the heart. The right ventricle pumps blood to the lungs for oxygenation, while the left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood to the rest of the body.

  • Relaxation: The heart muscles relax, allowing the chambers to fill with blood again.

  • Electrical Control: The heart's rhythm and coordination are controlled by electrical signals. The sinoatrial (SA) node, often referred to as the heart's natural pacemaker, initiates the electrical impulses that regulate heart rate. These impulses travel through specialized pathways, including the atrioventricular (AV) node and the bundle of His, to ensure coordinated contractions.

Blood Composition: Blood consists of various components that perform specific functions:

  • Red Blood Cells (RBCs): Red blood cells carry oxygen from the lungs to the body's tissues and transport carbon dioxide, a waste product, back to the lungs for elimination.

  • White Blood Cells (WBCs): White blood cells are crucial for the immune response. They help protect the body against infections, pathogens, and foreign substances.

  • Platelets: Platelets are small cell fragments involved in blood clotting. When a blood vessel is damaged, platelets aggregate to form a clot, preventing excessive bleeding.

  • Plasma: Plasma is a yellowish fluid that makes up the majority of blood volume. It carries nutrients, hormones, antibodies, waste products, and other substances throughout the body.
